source.08f0439d:
# Determining the age of females using 'Miss' title and 'Parch'

all_miss = train_data[train_data.Title=="Miss"]['Age']

fem_adult = train_data[(train_data.Title=="Miss") & (train_data.Parch==0)]['Age']

fem_child = train_data[(train_data.Title=="Miss") & (train_data.Parch!=0)]['Age']

print ("Average age of 'Miss' Title", all_miss.mean())

print ("Average age of 'Miss' Title travelling without Parents", fem_adult.mean())

print ("Average age of 'Miss' Title travelling with Parents", fem_child.mean())
source.70b459f7:

train_data.Age.fillna(train_data.groupby('Title').Age.transform(np.mean), inplace=True)
source.30182216:
# Filling test data with the mean ages of respective groups of train data to prevent test train leakage
test_data.Age.fillna(train_data.groupby('Title').Age.transform(np.mean), inplace=True)

source.d6a1f5f7:
# Look at the data type of the columns. Our machine learning model can easily 
# handle 'int' and 'float' (numerical) values but not 'object' (categorical) values
X.info()
source.4b9c8469:
# Hence we need to encode the categorical columns  
# We'll select the columns with low cardinality as labels with high cardinality lead to poor performance

categorical_cols = [col for col in X.columns if
                    X[col].nunique() < 10 and 
                    X[col].dtype == "object"]

# Select numerical columns
numerical_cols = [col for col in X.columns if 
                X[col].dtype in ['int64', 'float64']]

# To keep only the required columns
X = X[numerical_cols + categorical_cols].copy()
source.9df5959d:
# Let's encode test set columns too
categoricalcols = [col for col in X_test.columns if
                    X_test[col].nunique() < 10 and 
                    X_test[col].dtype == "object"]

# Select numerical columns
numericalcols = [col for col in X_test.columns if 
                X_test[col].dtype in ['int64', 'float64']]

# To keep only the required columns
X_test = X_test[numericalcols + categoricalcols].copy()

source.2239866a:
The features provided in the data are:

* Passenger Id: An ID given to each traveler on the boat
* Pclass: The passenger class. It has three possible values: 1,2,3 (first, second and third class)
* Name : The Name of the passenger
* Sex
* Age
* SibSp: Number of siblings and spouses traveling with the passenger
* Parch: Number of parents and children traveling with the passenger
* The ticket number
* The ticket Fare
* The cabin number
* The embarkation. This describe three possible areas of the Titanic from which the people embark. Three possible values S,C,Q
source.596110b0: Label Encoding refers to converting the labels into numeric form so as to convert it into the machine-readable form.
source.d4b11230:
Our next step is dealing with this missing data and you must be aware that we can do that in following ways:
1. Listwise deletion - It means deleting all data from any participant with missing values which is not possible here with 177 and 687 values missing in 'Age' and 'Cabin' column respectively. If we remove these rows we will lose 77.1% data. Although we can remove 2 rows containing missing values from 'Embarked' column.
2. Imputation - It means filling in the missing values by the average or median age of the rest of the passengers. But we have to calculate the mean ages of all the males, females and children(male an female) separately as we just saw that females have high survivl rate. If we impute the 'Age' column with the mean age of all the passengers, it may lead to underfitting.
source.2b3c405f: We have to predict the survival or the death of a given passenger based on the features given

source.fa1b7c50: Now, it's easy to determine the adult males and male  children with their titles 'Mr' and 'Master' respectively. But the titles of adult unmarried females and the female children is same, 'Miss'. One way to separate them is to consider that the females travelling without parents and children are more likely to be adults. While the females travelling with their parents are children.
